Susannah Kosty
UT EID: sk27622
Email: skosty@utexas.edu

To run, 

javac *.java
java Encoder <freqFile> <ncharacters> <compoundcharacterlength>

freqFile : the file with relative frequencies of occurence of characters. An alphabet is constructedby taking the segment of the English alphabet starting with A that is the same length as the number of probabilities provided. For example, the below file would produce the alphabet {A,B,C,D}

@freqFile

10
3
5
7

ncharacters: The number of characters to be encoded. 

compoundcharacterlength : The number of letters encoded at once. Any positive integer is allowed, although run times for values greater than 5 are very slow. Note, this code complies with the first extra credit requirement. 

There is a rounding error associated with compound character lengths that do not fit with no remainder within the total number of characters. What happens is that the last chunk of letters to be encoded is not actually, resulting in some data loss at the end of the stream of letters. For instance, if the total number of characters is 10, and the chunks are three characters long, only 9 characters will be encoded, the last being skipped. This effect may also result in slightly negative percent differences between language entropy and actual encoding efficiency, along with other imprecision and rounding errors. 


NOTE: This project uses precompiled files from another project. Specifically, the class arrayio and methods dlmread are used in importing numerical text from file, storing data into an array.

NOTE 2: Standard Output is redirected to log file. All entropy and efficiency output is shown at bottom of log file.  


Below is sample output: 

Frequency File: 
19
10
42
35
10
11
